statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.headline: Nash free throws seal it
article.linkText: Nowitzki scores 40 as Mavs edge Pistons
article.story:
DALLAS (AP) -- Dirk Nowitzki needed a little time to get warmed up against the Detroit Pistons. After missing his first five shots, Nowitzki went on to score 40 points -- nine in the final 6:40 -- in the Dallas Mavericks' 111-108 comeback victory over the Pistons on Saturday night. Steve Nash added 29 points, 11 assists and hit six straight free throws in the final 18.5 seconds to help the Mavericks win for the 12th time in their last 14 games. "Dirk got off to somewhat of a slow start, but after that he put on a clinic," said Nash, who was celebrating his 30th birthday. "He was aggressive and carried us for long stretches." Nowitzki made 15 of his last 19 field-goal attempts and hit three of four 3-pointers, helping his team shoot 55 percent from the field (41-for-74) to overcome Detroit's 56-32 advantage in points in the paint. "I just rushed my first couple of shots," Nowitzki said. "Then I started driving to the basket and that helped me find my rhythm. Once my first shot fell, I felt great." Chauncey Billups scored 17 points, Richard Hamilton had 16 and Corliss Williamson added 15 for the Pistons, who lost their third straight. Detroit was ahead by as many as six early in the fourth quarter, but Dallas took the lead for good at 101-100 on Antoine Walker's follow shot with 2:21 to play. Nowitzki's 18-footer with 1:35 left gave Dallas a 105-102 lead. Nowitzki then came up with a big defensive play on Detroit's next possession, blocking Hamilton's shot in the lane and collecting the rebound with 56.9 seconds left. "We stepped it up (defensively) and played big in the second half," Nowitzki said. Detroit had an opportunity to tie it, but Billups shot an airball on a 3-pointer with 21 seconds remaining, keeping Dallas in front 105-102. Nash's six free throws in the final 20 seconds closed out the Pistons. Detroit won the other meeting between the teams, 115-102 on Jan. 11. Nowitzki took control in the third quarter, scoring 17 of Dallas' 23 points and hitting seven of eight field-goal attempts as the Mavericks grabbed a 78-77 edge entering the fourth quarter. Nowitzki had a four-point play (a 3-pointer and a free throw) in the third quarter and hit another 3-pointer with 49 seconds left in the third to give the Mavericks their one-point lead heading into the fourth. The Pistons are one of the league's top defensive teams, but they were unable to contain Nowitzki and Nash. "The shots they weren't making in the first quarter they were making in the third and fourth," Billups said. "That's why they're so good. When those guys get going, it's like, Pick your poison." Detroit led by 15 (47-32) midway through the second quarter. But Dallas closed with a 23-11 run led by Nash's 10 points to cut it to 58-55 at halftime. Dallas finished the second quarter with a 10-0 spurt. "That's as bad as we've played all year," Pistons coach Larry Brown said of his team's play at the end of the first half. "We turned the ball over, got selfish and couldn't guard anyone." The Pistons shot 57.5 percent from the field in the first half (23-for-40), held a 23-10 rebounding edge at halftime and outscored the Mavericks in the paint, 30-16.

Game notes
Mavericks owner Mark Cuban was a guest player-coach for the New York Nationals against the Harlem Globetrotters in a game played earlier Saturday at American Airlines Center. Cuban was in the game for only a few minutes, but he did score on a wide-open 15-foot jumper. He even played a part in the Globetrotters' famed confetti-in-a-water-bucket gag except there was no confetti as Cuban was doused with water during a time out. "It was a dream come true," Cuban said. "It was a blast watching all the fans and kids having a great time." ... Mavericks F Eduardo Najera won't be back from the injured list (sore left knee) until after the All-Star break. Coach Don Nelson said Najera had a recent "setback" due to some swelling in the knee.
